Prevalence of HPV, cytological abnormalities, and impact of the HPV vaccine in Mexico: a Nationwide Study of 596,944 women 48 25 6 2025 101156 Lancet Regional Health - Americas 10.1016/j.lana.2025.101156 PMC12246922 40657432 pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes The recent study by Abraham García-Gil et al. 1 2 3 Persistent HPV infection in men contributes to elevated risk for a spectrum of malignancies, with oropharyngeal, penile and anal cancers being the most clinically significant. In the United States, oropharyngeal cancer in men has now surpassed cervical cancer as the most common HPV-related malignancy. 4 5 Neglect of male HPV prevalence will impede attainment of the WHO “Global cervical cancer elimination” targets and impose an enduring burden on public-health systems. We therefore propose three urgent measures for lower and middle-income countries: First, embed gender-neutral, stigma-free HPV education into routine primary-care encounters. Second, launch organized screening programmes combining HPV testing with targeted oropharyngeal and anal cancer screening for high-risk population, especially men who have sex with men. Third, implement a phased, government-funded HPV vaccination strategy that initially prioritises high-risk male cohorts and subsequently expands to encompass all adolescent boys. Contributors Bingmeng Xie wrote the original draft. Lifeng Xiao designed and supervised the overall project. Lin Peng reviewed and edited the manuscript.
